'''Darrell Nulisch''' (born September 14, 1952, [[Dallas, Texas]])<ref name="Oldies"/> is an [[United States|American]] [[electric blues]] [[singing|singer]] and [[harmonica]] player. Prior to his [[solo (music)|solo]] career, he was a member of [[Anson Funderburgh|Anson Funderburgh and the Rockets]] and [[Ronnie Earl|The Broadcasters]]. Nulisch's repertoire incorporates [[soul music|soul]] combined with [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]] and [[Chicago blues]], redesigned to complement his distinctive [[human voice|vocals]].<ref name="Oldies"/>

==Biography==
Nulisch was raised listening to [[Otis Redding]] and [[Al Green]]. In 1981 he was a founding member of [[Anson Funderburgh]]'s Rockets and sang with them until 1985. He was then part of [[Mike Morgan (blues musician)|Mike Morgan's Crawl]], before moving to [[Massachusetts]] and joining up with [[Ronnie Earl]]'s Broadcasters in 1988.<ref name="Oldies">{{cite web|url=http://www.oldies.com/artist-biography/Darrell-Nulisch.html |title=Darrell Nulisch Biography |publisher=Oldies.com |date=1952-09-14 |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref> 

He began his solo career late in 1990, relocating to [[Boston]]. [[James Cotton]] then asked him to sing with Cotton's band on tour, after Cotton had lost his own [[human voice|voice]].<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|author=Bradley Torreano |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/darrell-nulisch-mn0000566086/biography |title=Darrell Nulisch | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date=1952-09-14 |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref> Nulisch appeared on [[Otis Grand]]'s 1996 album, ''Perfume and Grime'', which also utilized [[Luther Allison]].<ref name="russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray
| edition= 
| publisher= Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| pages= 114–115
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref> 

Several of the songs in Nulisch's repertoire are his own, most of them written with Steve Gomes, who plays [[bass guitar]] in Texas Heat, the band that backed Nulisch for a number of years. Other band members included Benjie Porecki ([[piano]]), [[Johnny Moeller]] (guitar) and Robb Stupka ([[drum]]s).<ref name="Oldies"/>

Nulisch issued ''I Like It That Way'' in 2000.<ref name="AMG"/> His [[fan (person)|fan]] base started to expand from this point.<ref name="Oldies"/> His latest release, ''Just for You'', was released in October 2009. It received a four star rating from [[Allmusic]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Hal Horowitz |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/just-for-you-mw0000830866 |title=Just for You - Darrell Nulisch | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=2009-10-20 |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref>

==Discography==
*''Orange Soda'' (1991) - [[Black Top Records|Black Top]] - Darrell Nulisch & Texas Heat
*''Business as Usual'' (1991) - Black Top
*''Bluesoul'' (1996) - Higher Plane Music
*''Whole Truth'' (1998) - [[Severn Records]]
*''I Like It That Way'' (2000) - [[Severn Records]]
*''Times Like These'' (2003) - [[Severn Records]]
*''Goin' Back to Dallas'' (2007) - [[Severn Records]]
*''Just for You'' (2009) - [[Severn Records]]<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/darrell-nulisch-mn0000566086/discography |title=Darrell Nulisch | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date=1952-09-14 |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref>
